replies.msg: 係囉黨媒黎，但段片又冇咩野仲拍得好好
破壞大學

https://twitter.com/laurelchor/status/1250915566954713088

China Daily is a mouthpiece for the Chinese Communist Party. It is owned by the CCP's Publicity Department. In February, the US State Department named China Daily an operative of the state, meaning it meets the definition of a foreign mission.

@WorldPressPhoto says its "advocacy of free inquiry, free expression, free speech, and a free press is stronger than ever". But it just awarded a media org owned by the govt that jailed more journalists than any other country in the world in 2019, according to @CPJAsia.

Not only that, but the video is about the #HongKongProtests, a movement that is fighting the CCP, and the very movement the CCP is suppressing. Again, China Daily is a state-owned CCP mouthpiece. That's a conflict of interest, to say the least.

A quick perusal of China Daily will show you what a joke it is. Just yesterday, it published an editorial saying "the economy [has] yet to recover from the battering it took as a result of the rioting that plagued Hong Kong".

Today, an article about Beijing's top HK official calling the Hong Kong a "weak link in national security" refers to the protests as "radicalism and street violence" that "undermin[ed] the rule of law". These are just small, recent examples.[/b]

The video itself, which does capture impressive, immersive footage, is not blatantly problematic, but it gives no context or background. WPP does not mention any conflict of interest on its website or in the 2-minute interview with the maker of the winning video.

It makes me very worried that @WorldPressPhotowould give
@ChinaDaily, a mouthpiece for the CCP, an award for a video about the #HongKongProtests. At the very very least, they could have added a disclaimer about the conflict of interest.

Winning the @WorldPressPhoto award gives @ChinaDaily
credibility it does not deserve, and give the Chinese government fodder to claim that it supports press freedom. It will in fact help the CCP to further suppress press freedom.

And yes, full disclaimer: I am a photojournalist and I submitted photos from the Hong Kong protests to this year's World Press Photo awards. I did not win any awards. (I am super glad that @NAsfouri did though!)

PS: I don't know why, but WPP deleted its tweet announcing China Daily's win.

https://twitter.com/laurelchor/status/1251044663072567297

An example of China Daily literally creating and spreading absurd fake news during the #hongkongprotests.
最勁就係狗裝甲車着火嗰張相

replies.msg: 真，內外完全協調唔到。

你係咪有病架，China Daily拍嘅片，你咁樣都推，你係唔睇清楚人哋個背景就推，定係本身有咩目的呢？

你係咪會行過三聯，見到嗰啲大公系列嘅《哭泣的城市》都會睇錯都係手足出版咁樣買10本派街坊？見到呢一種低能貼文真係好嬲。
